ARTICLE.TITLE: Biden says his campaign raised $26 million in the 24 hours after announcing Kamala Harris as his running mate
ARTICLE.TEXT:
© Drew Angerer/Getty Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden and his running mate Sen. Kamala Harris arrive at the Alexis Dupont High School in Wilmington, Delaware, on August 12, 2020. Drew Angerer/Getty

Joe Biden's presidential campaign raised $26 million in the 24 hours after he named Kamala Harris as his running mate, the former vice president told a fundraising Zoom call Wednesday night.

Among the contributors were 150,000 first-time donors, Biden added.

That number means the campaign may match or exceed what President Donald Trump and the Republican National Committee will raise for all of August, CNN reported.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

Joe Biden's presidential campaign raised $26 million in the day after he named Sen. Kamala Harris of California as his running mate.

The former vice president made the announcement at a virtual grassroots fundraiser after he and Harris held their first campaign event in Wilmington, Delaware, Wednesday night, according to CNN.

Among the contributors in the first 24 hours after Biden announced Harris as his vice-presidential pick were 150,000 first-time donors, Politico reported him as saying.

"The response has been overwhelming. In the last 24 hours, we've raised $26 million. One hundred and fifty thousand of you [were] first-time contributors," Biden told the virtual fundraiser, according to CNN.

"It's really palpable, the excitement, because there's so much at stake."

CNN said that the haul brought in by the Harris announcement means the Biden campaign is likely to match or exceed the amount to be raised by President Donald Trump's campaign and the Republican National Committee in all of August.

While Biden topped Trump in fundraising for May and June, the president outmatched him in July by $30 million, according to Politico.
